text.1: The explanation regarding the hijaiyah letters at the beginning of several surahs in the Qur'an, such as at the beginning of this surah, has been elaborated at length at the beginning of Surah al-Baqarah. (See "Al-Qur'an dan Tafsirnya" Volume I)
text.2:
In this verse, Allah explains that the Holy Qur'an, which is the holy book for Prophet Muhammad and his followers, must have its contents and guidance practiced. It is the last holy book that confirms the previous holy books and is truly revealed from Allah, the Lord of the universe, the Almighty Lord, no creature can defeat Him, the All-Knowing Lord, nothing is hidden from Allah, no matter how small and subtle. Allah says:

"The revelation of the Book is from Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise." (al-A.hqaf/46: 2)

The Holy Qur'an could not possibly be made by anyone other than Allah, nor could it be made by Muhammad saw, as accused by the enemies of Islam. This has been affirmed by Allah in the Qur'an with His words:

"And it was not [possible] for this Qur'an to be produced by other than Allah." (Yunus/10: 37)

And His words:

"Or do they say, "He invented it?"" (Yunus/10: 38)

Indeed, the Holy Qur'an was revealed with diverse backgrounds, containing guidance for mankind to bring them out of darkness into the light. Allah says:

"[This is] a Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that you might bring mankind out of darknesses into the light by permission of their Lord - to the path of the Exalted in Might, the Praiseworthy." (Ibrahim/14: 1)
text.3:
In this verse, five attributes of Allah who revealed the Qur'an are explained:

1. Forgiver of Sins

This attribute of Allah is also affirmed in other verses, as in Allah's saying:

Inform My servants that it is I who am the Forgiving, the Merciful. (al-Hijr/15: 49)

And His saying:

Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful. (az-Zumar/39: 53)

No matter how many sins a person has, if he sincerely asks forgiveness from Allah, then Allah will forgive all his sins as explained in the Hadith Qudsi as follows:

O My servants, you commit sins day and night, and I forgive all sins, so ask Me for forgiveness, and I will forgive you. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Dharr)

In another Hadith Qudsi, Allah also affirms:

Allah said, "O son of Adam! As long as you call upon Me and put your hope in Me, I will forgive you for what you have done and I will not mind. O son of Adam! If your sins were to reach the clouds of the sky, then you asked forgiveness of Me, I would forgive you and I would not mind." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Anas bin Malik)

2. Acceptor of Repentance

This attribute of Allah is also affirmed in another verse in the Qur'an:

Do they not know that it is Allah who accepts repentance from His servants. (at-Taubah/9: 104)

A person who has committed evil deeds such as oppression and others, then repents, regrets his actions, strengthens his faith, does good, and remains on the path of Allah, then Allah will accept his repentance, as in His saying:

But whoever repents after his wrongdoing and reforms, then indeed, Allah will accept his repentance. (al-Ma'idah/5: 39)

And His saying:

And indeed, I am the Perpetual Forgiver of whoever repents and believes and does righteousness and then continues in guidance. (Taha/20: 82)

And His saying again:

Except for those who repent and correct themselves and make evident [what they concealed]. Those - I will accept their repentance, and I am the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful. (al-Baqarah/2: 160)

3. His Punishment is Severe.

Regarding this, Allah says:

[That is] when they see that the power belongs to Allah entirely and that Allah is severe in punishment. (al-Baqarah/2: 165)

Those who do evil, wallow in sins such as denying and rejecting the verses of Allah, take a path that is astray, namely other than the path that He has shown and outlined, they are the ones who receive Allah's severe and harsh punishment, as in His saying:

They used to deny Our verses, so Allah seized them for their sins. And Allah is severe in penalty. (ali 'Imran/3: 11)

In another verse, Allah affirms:

Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah will have a severe punishment, and Allah is Exalted in Might, Avenger. (ali 'Imran/3: 4)

And His saying also:

Indeed, those who go astray from the way of Allah will have a severe punishment for having forgotten the Day of Account. (Shad/38: 26)

4. Bestower of Bounty.

Every bounty and blessing that we receive is from Allah as in His saying:

[As] a favor from Allah and a blessing. And Allah is Knowing and Wise. (al-Hujurat/49: 8)

And His saying:

And whatever you have of favor - it is from Allah. (an-Nahl/16: 53)

No human being, in any way, can give a definite number regarding the many bounties and blessings that Allah has given him, as in His saying:

And if you should count the favors of Allah, you could not enumerate them. (an-Nahl/16: 18)

5. Allah is One.

One of the attributes of Allah that must be believed is that He is One, there is no God but Him, there is no partner for Him, there is nothing like Him, as in Allah's saying:

There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing. (ash-Shura/42: 11)

If He had a partner, there would be another god who has the same power as His power, then this world would be destroyed as in Allah's saying:

If there had been within the heavens and earth gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined. So exalted is Allah, Lord of the Throne, above what they describe. (al-Anbiya'/21: 22)

Those who say that Allah is one of the three belong to the group of deniers and disbelievers, because Allah is actually One, there is no God but Him, Allah's saying:

They have certainly disbelieved who say, "Allah is the third of three." And there is no god except one God. And if they do not desist from what they are saying, there will surely afflict the disbelievers among them a painful punishment. (al-Ma'idah/5: 73)

This verse ends with an affirmation that all creatures will return to Allah and there they will be perfected in the reward for them according to their respective deeds as in Allah's saying:

And fear a Day when you will be returned to Allah. Then every soul will be compensated for what it earned, and they will not be treated unjustly. (al-Baqarah/2: 281)
text.4:
In this verse, Allah explains that only the disbelievers are displeased with the truth, fond of arguing, opposing, and denying the contents of the Qur'an, and accusing it of falsehoods. Among their statements are that the Qur'an is merely poetry, magic, tales of the ancients, or other belittling accusations. In fact, it is clear and generally known that all the contents of the Qur'an are true. A debate that questions the contents of the Qur'an is a very reprehensible act and constitutes disbelief, as the Prophet Muhammad said:

"Arguing about the contents of the Qur'an is disbelief." (Narrated by Ahmad from Abu Hurairah)

However, a debate that questions something with the intention of seeking and strengthening what is right, clarifying what is still unclear, deriving a legal understanding, rejecting deviant beliefs and understandings that are not in accordance with Islamic teachings, and opposing understandings that belittle the contents of the Qur'an, is a good and commendable act. In fact, such is the task of the prophets.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns the Prophet Muhammad not to be deceived by the luxury obtained by his opponents, their freedom of movement from one city to another, buying and selling as they please, thus accumulating wealth. In any case, all of this has a limit, and is temporary, at most equal to their lifespan. After that, they will receive a most painful torment in the Hereafter. Allah says:

"Let not the free movement of the disbelievers throughout the land deceive you. It is but a brief enjoyment; then their [final] refuge is Hell, and wretched is the destination." (ali 'Imran/3: 196-197)
text.5:
In this verse, Allah comforts Prophet Muhammad so that he would not be anxious and agitated in facing his people who always opposed and denied him. Such is the *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way) that applies to every prophet and messenger sent by Allah. The people of Noah denied Prophet Noah, and so did other communities, who denied the prophets and messengers sent to them, such as the people of 'Ad, Thamud, and others. In fact, besides denying the messengers, they also plotted against them. They tried to fight their messengers and persecute them as they pleased. They relentlessly opposed, denied, and debated the messengers with false and baseless arguments. Among their statements was that the messengers were ordinary people like them, with the intention of rejecting the truth, obscuring the *haq* (truth) that came from Allah, and constantly extinguishing and suppressing the light (religion) of Allah, as Allah says:

"They want to extinguish the light of Allah with their mouths, but Allah refuses except to perfect His light, although the disbelievers dislike it." (at-Taubah/9: 32)

Allah did not remain silent in the face of these evil deeds that showed their moral depravity. They were punished with a very painful torment and destroyed by Allah, some even annihilated as if they had never existed on this earth. The *Ummah* of Muhammad saw, especially the people of Mecca, could witness the remnants of their destruction as narrated in the Qur'an:

"And indeed, you pass by them in the morning and at night. Then will you not reason?" (ash-shaffat/37: 137-138)
text.6:
This verse shows how past communities were punished and destroyed because of their inappropriate treatment of their prophets and messengers. Thus, this also applies to the community of Prophet Muhammad who continue to rebel, deny, and reject the verses of Allah. In the Hereafter, they will be cast into Hell. Allah says:

"And those who disbelieve and deny Our signs - those will be companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 39)
text.7:
This verse explains that the angels who carry the 'Arasy (Throne) and the angels who are around it constantly glorify Allah, express gratitude for His blessings, believe, and acknowledge that there is no god worthy of worship except Him. The angels also seek forgiveness for those who acknowledge the oneness and purity of Allah from worship of anything besides Him.

Regarding how the angels carry the 'Arasy and how many of them carry it, it is sufficient for us to believe as it is and return the knowledge of it to God, because such things are among the matters for which no details are found, either in the Al-Qur'an or in the mutawatir hadith.

In addition to glorifying and praising Allah, the angels also constantly pray for the believers. These prayers, among other things, describe the following:

First, that God's knowledge encompasses everything. Allah's mercy encompasses the forgiveness of their sins and mistakes, and God's knowledge encompasses their actions, words, and movements. It is easy for Allah to forgive sins and mistakes because His mercy is wider and greater than sins and mistakes. There is no action whatsoever in a dark place, no word or utterance, even a thought or whisper of the soul, no behavior or movement except that it is known by Allah.

Second, asking forgiveness from Allah for those who repent, stop the sins they have committed, follow what is commanded to them, practice good, and abandon evil.

Third, the angels also pray that the believers be protected from the torment of Hell Jahannam in accordance with Allah's promise.
text.8:
In this verse, the next prayer of the angels for the believers is explained:

Fourth, the angels plead that the believers be admitted into the Gardens of 'Adn, which Allah has promised through the words of His Messenger. The angels also plead that along with them be admitted the righteous among their fathers, their wives, and all their descendants, so that they may be happy to be gathered with their families in a place that can give joy and pleasure, arousing a deeply impressive feeling of cheerfulness and joy.

Sa'id bin Jubair explained that when a man enters Paradise, he says, "O Lord! Where are my father, grandmother, and mother? Where are my children and grandchildren? Where is my wife?" It is answered that they did not perform deeds like the deeds he has done. He then says, "O Lord! I did good deeds for myself and for them." So they are equated in status in Paradise, and he then recites this verse. In line with this verse is the word of Allah:

"And those who believe and whose descendants follow them in faith - We will join with them their descendants, and We will not deprive them of anything of their deeds. Every person, for what he earned, is retained." (ath-Thur/52: 21)

This verse is concluded with an affirmation that Allah is the All-Mighty, nothing can hinder His will, the All-Wise, nothing He does is except in accordance with the wisdom of His wisdom.
text.9:
This verse continues to explain the angels' subsequent prayer for the believers.

Fifth, the angels not only ask for forgiveness for the believers for their sins after repentance, but also for the sins and consequences of evil deeds they committed before they repented, so that they may be erased and not punished for them. Those who are forgiven, pardoned, and have the consequences of their evil deeds erased in this world, it means they have received a favor from Allah and are freed from His torment and punishment on the Day of Judgment. Such a thing is a very great victory because with good deeds that are not so significant, they obtain blessings and favors that are continuous and never-ending.
text.10:
In this verse, Allah explains that in the afterlife, the disbelievers who are in hell experience a very painful torment, hating and cursing each other. They even hate themselves for the deeds they committed in the world that caused them to enter hell. However, the angels say to them, "Indeed, Allah's hatred at the time you rejected the call of the prophets is greater than your hatred for yourselves when facing the torment of hell." Allah's word:

"Close friends, that Day, will be enemies to each other, except for the righteous." (az-Zukhruf/43: 67)

And His word:

"Then, on the Day of Resurrection, you will deny one another and curse one another..." (al-'Ankabut/29: 25)
text.11:
After hearing the call of the angels and being unable to bear the excruciating torment, the disbelievers said, "Our Lord, You have caused us to die twice and given us life twice. You made us in a state of death, then gave us life by breathing the spirit into our mothers' wombs, then caused us to die in the world after our appointed time ended, and in the Hereafter, You will resurrect us by returning our spirits to be resurrected." Allah says:

How can you deny Allah when you were lifeless and He gave you life; then He will cause you to die and then bring you [back] to life, and then to Him you will be returned. (al-Baqarah/2: 28)

Humans are dead when they are still fetuses and in their parents' bodies. Then they are given life when they are born into the world, then the next death is a necessity. After that, they are given life on the Day of Resurrection (the Day of Judgment). They experience life twice and death twice.

After witnessing Allah's power to cause them to die and live repeatedly, the disbelievers become aware. They acknowledge their mistakes in the world when they denied the Day of Resurrection and committed countless sins, in order to atone for those mistakes. They ask to be taken out of Hell and returned to the world to do good deeds and will not commit mistakes and sins again. This kind of request is also mentioned in another verse as Allah says:

If you could but see when the criminals are hanging their heads before their Lord, [saying], "Our Lord, we have seen and heard, so return us [to the world]; we will work righteousness. Indeed, we are [now] certain." (as-Sajdah/32: 12)

Our Lord, remove us from it, and if we were to return [to evil], we would indeed be wrongdoers. (al-Mu'minun/23: 107)
text.12:
In this verse, it is explained that their request cannot possibly be granted by Allah. They will not be returned to the world, because their hearts no longer accept the truth. In the world, they were disbelieving and denying when called upon to worship Allah alone, but when Allah was associated with others, they believed and affirmed it. Their request to leave hell and be returned to the world to do good deeds is answered by Allah with His word:

"He (Allah) will say, "Remain therein in disgrace, and do not speak to Me." (al-Mu’minun/23: 108)

Even if their request were granted and they were returned to the world, they would still do the things that Allah forbade, just as they did before. They are liars, as Allah says:

"But if they were returned [to the world], they would surely revert to that which they were forbidden. And indeed, they are liars." (al-An’am/6: 28)

This verse is concluded with a firm statement that the judgment on the Day of Judgment is in the hands of Allah, who will give judgment with truth and justice, the Most High and the Most Great, there is nothing like Him. God hates those who associate partners with Him and has implemented the wisdom of perpetuating them in hell.
text.13: This verse explains that Allah shows signs of His power, such as the existence of wind, clouds, thunder, lightning, storms, the sun, the moon, stars, and so on. He also sends down rain from the sky, so that trees grow and produce fruits of various colors, tastes, shapes, and forms. All of this demonstrates the power of Allah. Only those who return to Allah and are obedient to Him can take a lesson (iktibar) from the aforementioned signs, and understand that all of them are signs and proofs of Allah's power and oneness.
text.14:
At the end of the verse above, it is stated that those who realize the power and oneness of Allah are only those who return to Him. We should worship and supplicate to Him sincerely, purifying worship to Him, not associating partners with Him, as explained in the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from 'Abdullah bin Zubair:

That the Messenger of Allah, after completing the obligatory prayer, recited La ilaha illallah...and so on (meaning) There is no god but Allah, there is no partner for Him. To Allah belongs all dominion, to Him belongs all praise, and He is powerful over all things. There is no power and no strength except with the help of Allah. There is no god but Allah. We worship none but Him. To Him belong all blessings, favors, and good praise. There is no god but Allah, being sincere in devotion to Him, even though the disbelievers dislike it. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from 'Abdullah bin Zubair)
text.15:
In this verse, Allah mentions three of His glories and grandeurs, after mentioning in the previous verse the signs of His greatness and oneness.

a. Exalted is His degree. Allah is far Higher and more Magnificent than everything that exists. This is because everything other than Allah is in need of Him and not the other way around. He is eternal and everlasting, having no beginning and no end. He knows everything, as explained in the Qur'an:

And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him. (al-An'am/6: 59)

b. Possessing the 'Arasy (Throne). Allah possesses the 'Arasy and He is the One who governs it. He is the One who controls the material and immaterial realms.

c. Sending down revelation. Allah sends down His revelation containing commands, whether in the form of orders or prohibitions, to whomever He wills and conveys His laws to whomever He wills. This is also stated in another verse, as Allah says:

He sends down the angels with the revelation by His command upon whom He wills of His servants, [saying], "Warn [them] that there is no deity except Me; so fear Me." (an-Nahl/16: 2)

And His saying:

And indeed, this [Qur'an] is the revelation of the Lord of the worlds. The Trustworthy Spirit has brought it down Upon your heart, [O Muhammad] - that you may be of the warners. (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 192-194)

Allah sends down revelation to warn mankind about the Day of Judgment, which is when those who worship and those who are worshipped meet, settling all matters, all the entanglements that have not been resolved in the world.
text.16:
On the Day of Judgment, people will emerge from their graves. Not a single one of their deeds will be hidden from Allah; He knows everything. Then they will receive recompense according to their deeds; if good, they will be rewarded with good, and if evil, they will be rewarded with torment and punishment. Allah says:

"That Day you will be exhibited [before Him], not concealed will be any secret of yours." (al-Haqqah/69: 18)

At that time, Allah will say, "Whose is the kingdom today?" No one in the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar) will answer. Then Allah Himself will answer with His words, "It is Allah's, the One, the Prevailing." There is no partner for Him. The One who overcomes everything with His power and might.
text.17:
Even though Allah is All-Powerful and All-Mighty, and no one can prevent or hinder His will, He remains just towards His servants. In the Hereafter, Allah rewards each person according to their efforts and deeds in the world. No one will be wronged or harmed on that day. Those who do good will be rewarded with good without any reduction, and those who do evil will be recompensed according to their evil deeds. The reward for their evil deeds will not be increased in the slightest. No one will have their reckoning and accounting of deeds delayed or postponed. Allah is swift in reckoning. There is no reckoning and accounting as swift as Allah's reckoning. He reckons all His creation as He reckons a single person, because His knowledge is vast and encompasses everything that exists. There is no difference to Him when He creates and resurrects mankind from the graves simultaneously, as Allah says:

"The creation of you all and your resurrection is only like (the creation and resurrection of) a single soul (easy)." (Luqman/31: 28)

And His saying:

"And Our command is but one word, like a twinkling of the eye." (al-Qamar/54: 50)
text.18: In this verse, Allah explains that He commanded the Messenger of Allah to warn his polytheistic people about the coming of the Day of Judgment, which is not far off. Therefore, they are reminded to stop committing evil deeds that are forbidden by religion, and to correct their misguided creed, which will cause them to be punished later in the Hereafter with a painful torment. On that day, the situation will be very terrible and frightening, the sadness will be immeasurable so that the heart feels tight up to the throat, the breath goes up and down, life goes in and out until they meet their death. There will be no one who can help those who have wronged themselves by associating partners with Allah, and there will be no advocate to intercede.
text.19:
In this verse, Allah explains that He knows the treacherous look of the eyes and the deceitful gaze. The treacherous look of the eyes refers to looking at forbidden things in secret, so that others do not know.

Ibn 'Abbas gives an example of the treacherous look of the eyes, as narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim, Ibn Abi Shaybah, and Ibn al-Mundhir: a person is among his people, then a woman passes by them. He shows his people that he closes his eyes and does not see the woman passing by. If his people are not paying attention to him, he opens his eyes and looks at the woman. But if his people see him, he lowers his gaze again, hiding his gaze. Allah knows that in the heart of that man is hidden the intention to see the *aurat* of the woman passing by. Allah says:

And Allah is Knowing of that within the breasts. (at-Tagabun/64: 4)

And His saying:

Say, "Whether you conceal what is in your breasts or reveal it, Allah knows it." (ali 'Imran/3: 29)

If what is hidden, like the whispers of the heart, is known by Allah, then surely what is manifest and around us, what is in the heavens and on earth, what is sent down from the heavens and what ascends from it is even more so, as Allah says:

...He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them... (al-Baqarah/2: 255)

And His saying:

He knows what is in the heavens and earth, and He knows what you conceal and what you declare. (at-Tagabun/64: 4)

And His saying again:

He knows what penetrates into the earth and what emerges from it, and what descends from the heaven and what ascends therein. (Saba'/34: 2)
text.20:
In this verse, Allah explains that He will justly punish those who are treacherous and deceitful with their eyes, and those who conceal evil intentions and desires in their hearts. Allah rewards with Paradise those who lower their gaze to avoid seeing what is forbidden, and a painful punishment for those who repeatedly look and resolve in their hearts to do something religiously prohibited. No one is wronged. The consequences of a person's actions will return to them individually; they will not be oppressed in the slightest, as Allah says:

"Whoever does righteousness - it is for his [own] soul; and whoever does evil [does it] against it. And your Lord is not ever unjust to [His] servants." (Fushshilat/41: 46)

As for the idols and other objects of worship that the polytheists worship, they are powerless and cannot punish with anything, because they know nothing and have no power whatsoever. At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah is All-Hearing of all speech, both open and whispered, even the whispers of the heart; He hears them. Allah is All-Seeing of everything a person does, whether in a bright place or in a dark place.
text.21: In this verse, the disbelievers of Mecca who deny the truth of the message of the Prophet Muhammad are asked to visit the ruins of historical relics of previous peoples whom Allah destroyed. They can witness them every time they pass through these places on their trade journeys to the north or south. These were nations physically stronger than the disbelievers of Mecca, for example, the people of 'Ad, the people of Thamud, and others. Besides being physically stronger, they were also blessed by Allah with prosperity, a large population, excellence in construction, expertise in agriculture, and so on, so that they were advanced and highly cultured. However, the progress and high culture they possessed made them arrogant and forgetful, then they denied the messengers who were sent to them, even some of these messengers were injured or even killed. Because of these sins and outrageous behavior, Allah inflicted punishment upon them. Their agriculture was destroyed, their magnificent buildings were demolished, and their possessions were annihilated, so that they suffered and were miserable. Nothing could stop the destruction they experienced, and nothing could save them from suffering. This should be a lesson for the disbelievers of Mecca, and anyone who comes after them, that those who disbelieve will surely be punished by Allah, both in this world and in the Hereafter.
text.22:
The primary reason Allah inflicted punishment upon them was their disbelief (kufr). They refused to accept the truth brought by the messengers, that there is no God but Allah, that humans need to do good in this life, and that there is an afterlife where humans will receive the recompense for their deeds.

What the prophets conveyed was the absolute truth and undeniable, but they opposed it. When Allah punishes, His punishment is severe. Because of that disobedience, Allah destroyed them. That is the consequence of disobedience to the truth of religion. These events should serve as a lesson for the disbelieving people of Mecca who were rebelling against the invitation of the Prophet Muhammad. They should immediately realize and cease their wickedness because they too could experience the same fate as those previous communities.
text.23:
In these two verses, it is emphasized that Prophet Musa (Moses) was sent by Allah as His Messenger to Pharaoh, Haman, and Qarun to call them to believe. Pharaoh was the King of Egypt who considered himself a god. Haman was his prime minister. Meanwhile, Qarun was the wealthiest merchant and rich man at that time. These three are specifically mentioned in this verse because they were personally responsible for the influence they instilled in the people of Egypt to deny Prophet Musa and worship Pharaoh. If these three people had believed, the people of Egypt would have immediately believed as well.

Prophet Musa was sent by Allah to them carrying the teachings in the holy book of the Torah and the miracles given to him. The core teaching conveyed by Prophet Musa to them was to believe in the One God, do good, and believe in the afterlife where humans receive the recompense for their deeds. Among his miracles were his staff turning into a snake and his luminous hand. However, they rejected the teaching and disobeyed, even declaring themselves gods. A series of events of Prophet Musa's da'wah (proselytization) towards Pharaoh are revealed in the following verses:

Has there reached you the story of Moses? When his Lord called him in the sacred valley of Tuwa, [saying], "Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed. And say, 'Would you [be willing to] purify yourself And [let me] guide you to your Lord so you might fear [Him]?'" And he showed him the greatest sign. But he denied and disobeyed. Then he turned his back, striving. And he gathered [his people] and called out, Saying, "I am your most exalted lord." So Allah seized him with the punishment of the Hereafter and the first [life]. Indeed in that is a lesson for whoever fears [Allah]. (an-Nazi'at/79: 15-26)

Witnessing Prophet Musa's miracles and his invitation to believe, Pharaoh accused Prophet Musa of being a sorcerer and a great liar. In another verse, it is mentioned that Pharaoh accused Prophet Musa of being a sorcerer and insane:

But they turned away and said, "A magician or a madman." (adz-dzariyat/51:39)

That accusation was conveyed by Pharaoh after his sorcerers were unable to defeat Prophet Musa's miracle, which was his staff turning into a snake and swallowing the snakes that came from the mines bewitched by the sorcerers. In fact, the sorcerers turned away from Pharaoh and believed in Allah.
text.24:
In these two verses, it is emphasized that Prophet Musa (Moses) was sent by Allah as His Messenger to Pharaoh, Haman, and Qarun to call them to believe. Pharaoh was the King of Egypt who considered himself a god. Haman was his prime minister. While Qarun was the wealthiest merchant and rich man at that time. These three are specifically mentioned in this verse because they were personally responsible for the influence they instilled in the people of Egypt to deny Prophet Musa and worship Pharaoh. If these three people had believed, the people of Egypt would have immediately believed as well.

Prophet Musa was sent by Allah to them carrying the teachings in the holy book of the Torah and the miracles given to him. The core of the teachings conveyed by Prophet Musa to them was to believe in the One God, do good, and believe in the afterlife where humans receive the recompense for their deeds. Among his miracles were his staff turning into a snake and his hand shining brightly. However, they rejected the teachings and rebelled, even declaring themselves to be gods. A series of events of Prophet Musa's da'wah (call to Islam) to Pharaoh are revealed in the following verses:

Has there come to you the story of Moses? When his Lord called him in the sacred valley of Tuwa, [saying], "Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed. And say, 'Would you [be willing to] purify yourself And [let me] guide you to your Lord so you might fear [Him]?'" And he showed him the greatest sign. But he denied and disobeyed. Then he turned away, striving [against Allah]. Then he gathered [his people] and called out and said, "I am your most exalted lord." So Allah seized him with the punishment of the Hereafter and the former [life]. Indeed in that is a lesson for those who fear [Allah]. (an-Nazi'at/79: 15-26)

Witnessing Prophet Musa's miracles and his invitation to believe, Pharaoh accused Prophet Musa of being a sorcerer and a great liar. In another verse, it is mentioned that Pharaoh accused Prophet Musa of being a sorcerer and insane:

But they turned away and said, "A magician or a madman." (adz-dzariyat/51:39)

That accusation was conveyed by Pharaoh after his sorcerers were unable to defeat Prophet Musa's miracle, which was his staff that turned into a snake and swallowed the snakes that came from the mines bewitched by the sorcerers. In fact, the sorcerers turned away from Pharaoh and believed in Allah.
text.25:
Prophet Musa explained to Pharaoh, Haman, and Qarun about Allah as the One and Only God and the obligation of humans to believe and do good, as well as about his prophethood. However, they were very angry. They refused to accept what Prophet Musa conveyed because it contradicted the belief that had been instilled in the people of Egypt that Pharaoh was God. Also, because the teachings brought by Prophet Musa could endanger their power and position. Then they ordered the male children of the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) to be killed and to let their female children live.

The order to kill the male children of the Bani Israil was the second order. The first order was issued by Pharaoh on the advice of his astrologers who interpreted his dream that a male child would be born from among the Bani Israil who would overthrow him and destroy his kingdom. The purpose of the killing was to weaken the Bani Israil, because their men would be exhausted, while their women could be controlled. It also aimed to exterminate the Bani Israil ethnicity from the land of Egypt because they could defeat the native Egyptians themselves. However, Allah had another plan. With His plan, Allah actually made Musa, who was still a baby, be cared for and raised in Pharaoh's palace as his son. After growing up, Musa had to leave Egypt because his life was threatened as a result of killing an Egyptian.

The second order to kill every male baby of the Bani Israil was issued by Pharaoh after Prophet Musa returned to Egypt as a prophet who was ordered by Allah to awaken Pharaoh and invite him to believe. According to Ibn Kathir, Pharaoh's aim in killing the male children of the Bani Israil was to instill dissatisfaction among the followers of Prophet Musa themselves towards him. Because with the second threat of murder, it meant that Prophet Musa had caused them two difficulties, first when Prophet Musa was not yet born and second after he became a prophet who called Pharaoh. In Pharaoh's mind, if the Bani Israil were not satisfied with him, then Prophet Musa would be defeated by his own people. This possibility is narrated in the Qur'an:

They (the people of Musa) said, "We were oppressed before you came to us and after you have come to us." He said, "Perhaps your Lord will destroy your enemy and make you successors in the land, so He will see how you will do." (al-A'raf/7: 129).

However, that intention was not achieved. The second plan to kill the male children of the Bani Israil failed completely, because Allah sent down various calamities as His punishment, such as the arrival of a devastating flood, the emergence of swarms of locusts, lice, frogs, and water that turned into blood (see al-A'raf/7: 133). The intention to prevent people from believing in Prophet Musa and the teachings he conveyed also did not succeed, because the truth cannot be denied and Allah's will must happen as He has said:

Allah has decreed, "I will surely overcome, I and My messengers." Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might. (al-Mujadilah/58: 21)
text.26:
Pharaoh not only intended to weaken the Children of Israel and eliminate their ethnicity, but also sought to destroy the religion of monotheism by killing the Prophet Musa (Moses) himself. He declared to his followers that he himself would carry out the killing and for that he asked not to be hindered. He was very confident that he could kill the Prophet Musa immediately. Therefore, he challenged the Prophet Musa to ask for help from his Lord.

The background to Pharaoh's plan to kill the Prophet Musa was his concern that the Prophet Musa would replace the religion of the Egyptian people with the religion of monotheism that he taught. Or, he was worried that the Prophet Musa would change the beliefs, habits, and customs of his people and eventually incite them to rebel against him, so that he would lose his power.
text.27:
When Prophet Musa (Moses) received news about Pharaoh's evil plan to kill him, he said to his people that he sought refuge in Allah, his Lord and their Lord as well. Prophet Musa was certain that Allah would surely protect him because he was on the side of truth, while Pharaoh was arrogant, evil, cruel, acted arbitrarily in Egypt, killed innocent people, and proclaimed himself as a god whose commands must be obeyed by all.

Pharaoh's actions were motivated by disbelief in the existence of the Hereafter, where every deed, no matter how small, would be held accountable. Pharaoh did not believe in the Hereafter, so he did not believe that if he acted cruelly in this world, he would be recompensed for it later in the afterlife. Such is the consequence of disbelief (kufr). Humans will act arbitrarily in this world, which can lead to its destruction.
text.28:
The scholars of tafsir narrate that the believing man mentioned in this verse was an Egyptian from Pharaoh's family. His name is unclear, but Ibn Kathir narrates from Ibn Abi Hatim that he was Pharaoh's uncle's son who secretly believed in Prophet Musa. No one from Pharaoh's family believed except for the person mentioned in this verse and Pharaoh's own wife, named Asiah. This man was the one who informed Prophet Musa about Pharaoh's evil plan to kill him. This is a narration from the source of Ibn 'Abbas. However, al-Khazin, as well as an-Nasafi, also narrate from the source of Ibn 'Abbas that the man's name was Sam'an or Habib. Some also mention Kharbil or Hazbil. What the scholars agree on is that the man was Pharaoh's uncle's son.

The believing man advised Pharaoh with full wisdom, "Is it fitting to kill a man who declares himself a believer in Allah, while he has conveyed reasons and clear evidence about what he believes in?" He continued that if Prophet Musa was lying, then the consequences of his lie would be borne by himself. However, if Prophet Musa was truthful, and he was tortured or killed, then some of what was threatened to the person who tortures or kills him would be received in this world as well, and in the hereafter he would enter hell.

He then affirmed that Allah will not guide those who act unjustly and lie. Meaning, Prophet Musa believed and brought evidence of his faith, while the one who is unjust and a liar is Pharaoh. Therefore, the one who will not receive guidance is Pharaoh. Not receiving guidance means being miserable in this world and entering hell in the hereafter. Thus, the one who will be miserable in this world and enter hell in the hereafter is Pharaoh.
text.29:
Furthermore, the believing man advised his people, the people of Egypt, that they had been given a great blessing by Allah. Egypt had become a great kingdom, respected and influential. Therefore, that blessing must be maintained by believing in Allah, and if they were to disbelieve, it was feared that that greatness would collapse and they would suffer. "Who will help us if disaster comes?" he said.

Such was the advice of the believing man to Pharaoh and his people. But that advice was not accepted by Pharaoh. He declared that what he said was what should be accepted and carried out, and what he conveyed and commanded was good and right. Thus, Pharaoh forced his will and again acted arbitrarily.

Pharaoh's answer was actually untrue, because in his heart of hearts, he actually affirmed what Prophet Musa conveyed. His words were actually only driven by his tyranny and arrogance, as stated in the following verse:

And they rejected them while in their (hearts) were convinced thereof, out of wrong and arrogance. (an-Naml/27: 14)

What Pharaoh said, that what he commanded his people was good, so that Prophet Musa must still be killed, was also far from the truth. This is because it is not true that by killing someone the problem will be solved, especially if the one being killed is a messenger of Allah. That action is precisely misguided and misleading, as stated in the following verse:

And Pharaoh led his people astray and did not guide (them). (thaha/20: 79).

Nevertheless, Pharaoh's followers accepted and obeyed his commands even though they were wrong, as revealed in the following verse:

To Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and the command of Pharaoh was not right. (Hud/11: 97)

Pharaoh's actions of deceiving his people and forcing them to follow his commands, and inciting them to deny the messenger of Allah, serve as a lesson for leaders. A leader who wants to hinder and distance society from their religious teachings may experience the same fate as Pharaoh. In this regard, the Messenger of Allah gave advice: "There is no Imam (leader) who dies, on the day of his death he has deceived his people, but he will not smell the fragrance of Paradise. Indeed, the fragrance of Paradise can be smelled from a distance of five hundred years of travel." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.30:
The believing man from Pharaoh's family conveyed to his people that he was extremely worried if they refused to believe and instead followed Pharaoh's orders. They would experience the same fate that had befallen previous communities. Those communities opposed and rejected the messengers sent by Allah, such as the people of Prophet Noah, the 'Ad people, Thamud, and the communities after them. They were all destroyed by Allah with various disasters as punishment, and no one could ward off or save themselves. That is what is meant by *yaumul ahzab* in this verse.

Such is Allah's punishment for those who disbelieve in the world. Allah does not act unjustly with that destruction, but they are the ones who wrong themselves by committing actions that result in His wrath. Allah only imposes punishment when the messenger has conveyed his message perfectly, and they cannot be reformed after being advised repeatedly. That event should be taken as a lesson by his people. The man hoped that his advice would be accepted by his people and that they would believe in Prophet Moses, not disobeying him, let alone killing him.

text.33:
After the believing man warned his people about the torment in this world, he continued his warning about the awfulness of the events of the Day of Judgment and the torment in the hereafter. When the Day of Judgment occurs, the earth will shake violently, causing people to run to and fro, shouting for help. However, who will help at that time, because every human being is experiencing the same event and is worried about their own fate.

Regarding *yaum at-tanad* (the Day of Mutual Calling), there are several opinions of scholars:

a. The Day of Judgment, so named because people at that time will shout for help from others while running to and fro, witnessing the earth shaking and splitting apart violently.

b. The day when the disbelievers in the hereafter are confronted with Hell, then they frantically run here and there to avoid it, but the angels intercept and drive them back to the Plain of Assembly (*Padang Mahsyar*) to be thrown into Hell.

c. The day when the angels weigh the deeds of humans. If a person's scale of good deeds turns out to be heavy, that person and those who witness it will shout with joy, declaring loudly that so-and-so is fortunate, and so on. Likewise, when a person receives a scale of good deeds lighter than their sins, they will lament sadly, followed by others.

d. Mutual calling between the inhabitants of Paradise and the inhabitants of Hell about what each has obtained. When the inhabitants of Paradise are asked by the inhabitants of Hell whether they have obtained what Allah promised them, they answer firmly that what was promised has been enjoyed. On the other hand, when the inhabitants of Hell are asked the same question by the inhabitants of Paradise, they also answer with the same words, but with a bitter voice, indicating that what they have obtained is misery.

On the Day of Assembly (*Mahsyar*), which is the Day of Allah's judgment, the disbelievers have already seen Hell. Therefore, they run away wanting to avoid it, but the angels intercept and return them to the Plain of Assembly. At that time, no one can help anyone else. Let alone helping others, they are not even sure they can help themselves. The believing man warned his people that he was very worried that this event would befall them. If they put their hope in Pharaoh, then he will be punished in Hell, unable to help himself, let alone help his followers.

The believing man asked his people to believe. He was very worried that their hearts would be closed if they still refused to accept the truth. If the heart is closed, no one will be able to open it except Allah.
text.34:
The person further stated that before Prophet Musa, Allah had sent Prophet Yusuf to the people of Egypt. Prophet Yusuf had invited them to believe and provided evidence of his prophethood, namely teachings about faith in Allah and doing good, as well as the miracles that Allah had bestowed upon him. However, they still refused to believe in him. They only obeyed him as a minister or a high-ranking official of the state. This shows that they were more influenced by the greatness of worldly positions than the position of a messenger, and that is why they preferred the cruel Pharaoh to Prophet Musa who brought the truth.

After Prophet Yusuf died, they declared that after him there would be no more messengers. They said that because they did not want another messenger to invite them to the truth. It turned out that there was a messenger, namely Prophet Musa, and that is why they disobeyed him and became misguided people. Thus, their misguidance was due to their greed for worldly splendor, as Pharaoh did. Their misguidance was also caused by their nature of always doubting the truth, even though what was conveyed to them was the revelation of Allah, which is certainly true.
text.35:
Then Allah explains how the actions of those who are greedy and always doubt the truth of revelation are. They always reject the truth of Allah's verses that are conveyed to them. They also always question the proofs presented regarding the truth of the revelation. However, their rejection has no strength whatsoever. Their belief is only based on the traditions of their ancestors, and it is merely blind obedience without thought. Such obedience is not justified because Allah has given humans hearing, sight, and intellect. Therefore, those who reject the truth of revelation and believe more in the traditions of their ancestors no longer know what is right and what is wrong. Thus, they are greatly hated by Allah and the believers.

Furthermore, Allah explains His laws for those who close their hearts to receiving the truth of revelation, namely that He will seal their hearts. A closed heart occurs because they always reject the truth of revelation and question it. Continuous rejection will lead to arrogance. Always questioning the truth will lead to arbitrariness. Because of arrogance and arbitrariness, they will always reject and oppose the truth. Finally, their hearts will close on their own. Such is the law determined by Allah for the sealing of human hearts.
text.36:
Pharaoh still did not accept the advice of one of his family members. He remained defiant and unwilling to accept the da'wah (invitation) of Prophet Musa (Moses). Therefore, he wanted to mock Prophet Musa. He ordered Haman, his prime minister, to build a large and magnificent palace that soared into the sky. In another verse, it is informed that the palace was built from bricks made of baked clay:

"And Pharaoh said, "O eminent ones, I have not known you to have a god other than me. Then ignite for me, O Haman, [a fire] upon the clay and make for me a tower that I may look at the God of Moses. And indeed, I do think he is among the liars." (al-Qashash/28: 38)

The purpose of building the large, magnificent, and towering structure was as a place or ladder to spy on or witness the existence of the God of Prophet Musa. He declared that Prophet Musa was actually a liar because he was certain that there was no God in the sky. The intention of his words was to deceive his people, that indeed there was no God in the sky as Prophet Musa had said. Thus, he wanted his people not to believe in Prophet Musa and to continue to follow him.

Pharaoh acted in this way because he was controlled by his ambition to defeat Prophet Musa. He was also controlled by the desire that his people would not find the truth conveyed by Prophet Musa. He wanted his people to continue to obey him, and for that, he did everything possible, from distorting the truth to mocking. Ambition and desire are what often lead humans astray, as depicted in the following Arabic poem:

The *nafs* (soul/desire) is like a baby; if you leave it, it will grow up

constantly wanting to suckle, but if you wean it,

it will be weaned on its own.

Then this verse is closed with an affirmation that Pharaoh's trickery to defeat Prophet Musa and extinguish the religion of *tawhid* (monotheism) that he brought failed and brought great losses. It failed because the *da'wah* of Prophet Musa could still not be contained. It was a loss because the costs he incurred were not small, while the results were nil. This is because Allah always destroys the falsehood that humans do and destroys the consequences left by the false deeds, as He has said:

"Indeed, those [disbelievers] - destroyed is that in which they are [presently] engaged, and worthless is what they have been doing." (al-A.'raf/7: 139)
text.37:

*Nafsu* (desire) is like a baby, if you let it be, it will grow up
