"Indeed, that [religion] in which they are will be destroyed, and worthless is what they have been doing." (al-A'raf/7: 139)
text.38:
Even though Pharaoh's people opposed him, the believer in Moses continued to call his people to follow the Prophet Moses. He said, "O my people, if you follow my call and you believe in what I have conveyed, it means you are following the straight path that leads to eternal happiness in the Hereafter, and it also means you have embraced the religion of Allah conveyed by Moses."

This verse provides guidance to believers to always convey the religion of Allah to mankind and invite them to the straight path in a good manner, even if the disbelievers deny it. This is one of the tasks that Allah places upon every believer. They should be steadfast and patient in carrying out this da'wah, as was done by the believer who followed the call of Moses.
text.39: In this verse, it is explained that the one who believed in Moses said to his people, "O my people, the life of this world is a fleeting life, where the pleasures and happiness obtained within it are pleasures and happiness that are imperfect and not eternal. As for the Hereafter, it is an eternal life, the pleasures and happiness obtained are perfect pleasures and happiness. Therefore, do not ever deny Allah in this worldly life so that you may avoid His punishment in the Hereafter."
text.40:
The believer explains to his people how great the influence of a person's worldly life is on their life in the hereafter. He said to his people, "O my people, whoever commits an evil deed, whether male or female, will only be punished according to the evil deed they committed. However, whoever believes and does righteous deeds, follows the commands of Allah and stops His prohibitions, then he will be admitted into Paradise full of delights. Allah rewards their faith and righteous deeds with multiplied rewards and limitless sustenance."

This verse illustrates the true justice of Allah, as well as His attributes of being the Most Compassionate and Most Merciful to His servants. He does not wrong His servants in the slightest. If He punishes His servants in the Hereafter, then the punishment given is balanced with the evil deeds and denial that they committed during their life in the world, not increased in the slightest. However, if He rewards the faith and righteous deeds of His servants, then He rewards them with multiplied rewards.
text.41: The man who believed in Moses repeated his call to his people, saying, "O my people, I am astonished by your attitude and actions. I call you to follow the path of salvation, to save you from the torment of Hell, and to lead you into Paradise by believing in Allah and performing righteous deeds, while you call me to the path of misery that leads to Hell."
text.42: Furthermore, the believer declared, "You all call and invite me to deny Allah and associate partners with Him, with something for which there is no true justification and no evidence that can be believed in its truth, stating that associating partners with God is the correct belief. While I call and invite you all to profess the oneness of Allah, there is no God other than Him. The All-Powerful, the All-Dominant, with clear evidence. He is the All-Powerful, the Oft-Forgiving of the sins of His servants."
text.43:
This verse continues the words of the believer mentioned above. He says, "Indeed, you have called me to worship idols, which do not hear the calls of those who call upon them, and cannot provide help either in this world or in the Hereafter, because they cannot inflict any harm nor provide any benefit to anyone." Allah says:

If you call upon them, they do not hear your call; and if they were to hear, they could not respond to you. And on the Day of Resurrection they will deny your association [of them with Allah]. And none can inform you like [one] Acquainted [with all matters]. (Fathir/35: 14)

And Allah says:

And who is more astray than one who calls upon besides Allah those who will not respond to him until the Day of Resurrection, and they, of their call, are unaware? (al-A.hqaf/46: 5)

The believer continued his speech, "Know, my people, that we all belong to Allah and to Him we shall return after death and be resurrected. At that time, He will reward us according to our deeds and actions. Those who disbelieve and transgress the limits will be inhabitants of Hell."
text.44:
Then, those who believed concluded their advice to their people by saying, "O my people, in the Hereafter you will all know the truth of what I conveyed to you, both in the form of Allah's commands and His prohibitions. At that time you will regret it, but at that time regret will be of no use. I put my trust in my Lord and I submit all my affairs to Him and I seek His help, so that I may be protected from all kinds of evil that I might commit and from all calamities that might befall me."

Indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of the condition of His servants. He guides His servants who deserve to be guided and leads astray His servants who desire that straying by doing forbidden deeds and not doing the commands that they must carry out.
text.45:
This verse explains that Allah helps His believing servants and destroys their enemies by stating that He protects those who believe from all the deceitful efforts and persecution carried out by Pharaoh and his followers by saving them along with Moses. Meanwhile, Pharaoh and his followers were drowned in the Red Sea. In the Hereafter, they will be afflicted with a painful torment.

It was narrated by Ibn 'Abbas, "When Pharaoh learned of the man's faith, he intended to kill him. Therefore, he fled to save himself."
text.46:
This verse describes the punishment that will befall Pharaoh and his rebellious people in the Hereafter. From the time of their death until they are resurrected, they will be presented to the Fire morning and evening, continuously until the Day of Judgment.

On the Day of Judgment, it will be said to the keepers of Hell, "Admit Pharaoh and his people into the Fire and inflict upon them the severest punishment."

The majority of scholars (Jumhur ulama) are of the opinion that the punishment of the grave exists, and its basis is this verse. Their opinion is strengthened by the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Umar:

That the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Indeed, when one of you dies, he is shown his seat morning and evening. If he is among the people of Paradise, then (his seat is) the seat of the people of Paradise, and if he is among the people of Hell, then (his seat is) the seat of the people of Hell. It is said to him, 'This is your seat until Allah resurrects you on the Day of Judgment.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn 'Umar)

From the word of Allah and the hadith above, it can be concluded that the punishment of the grave is a truth that cannot be denied and will be experienced by the disbelievers morning and evening until they are resurrected.

However, ar-Razi stated that the punishment of the grave does not exist. The verse cannot be used as a basis for establishing the existence of the punishment of the grave, but only shows the continuity of the punishment of Hell, similar to the word of Allah addressed to the people of Paradise:

And therein they will have their provision morning and evening. (Maryam/19: 62)
text.47:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to tell the polytheists of Mecca about the calamity that befell Pharaoh and his people, as well as the torment of the grave and the Hereafter that they will suffer later. This is so that the news becomes a lesson for them, so that they become aware and believe in Allah and His Messenger.

In that command, Prophet Muhammad is asked to tell the polytheists of Mecca about the arguments of the disbelievers who deny the call of the Messenger when they are in Hell later. The followers plead for help from their deities to be saved from the torment of Hell that is befalling them, or to reduce it. However, those deities disclaim responsibility for that request because they themselves are powerless to reduce or avoid the torment that is befalling them. The idol worshippers then accuse those deities, saying, "We were your worshippers in the world before, and we were your guardians who were always obedient to you and provided for all your needs, so that we denied the call of the Messenger that was conveyed to us. If we had not worshipped you during our life in the world, then we would have followed the call of the Messenger, so that we would not have been put into Hell as we are now. Will you prevent us from this torment or lighten it by your willingness to bear some of the torment that has befallen us? If it were not for you all, we would have been among the believers."
text.48:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to tell the polytheists of Mecca about the calamity that befell Pharaoh and his people, as well as the torment of the grave and the hereafter that they will suffer later. This is so that the news becomes a lesson for them, so they become aware and believe in Allah and His Messenger.

In that command, Prophet Muhammad is asked to tell the polytheists of Mecca about the arguments of the disbelievers who deny the call of the Messenger when they are in hell later. The followers plead for help from their deities to be saved from the torment of hell that is befalling them, or to reduce it. However, those deities disclaim responsibility for that request because they themselves are powerless to reduce or avoid the torment that is befalling them. The idol worshippers then accuse those deities, saying, "We were your worshippers in the world before, and we were your guardians who were always obedient to you and provided for all your needs, so we denied the call of the Messenger that was conveyed to us. If we had not worshipped you during our lives in the world, we would have followed the call of the Messenger, so we would not have been put into hell as we are now. Will you prevent us from this torment or lighten it by being willing to bear some of the torment that has befallen us? If it were not for you all, we would have been believers."
text.49: After the polytheists who are in Hell failed to obtain help from their leaders, they pleaded for help from the guardians of Hell, saying, "O guardians of Hell (Angel Malik), beseech Allah that He might lighten the torment that He has inflicted upon us. If relief could be given to us by returning us to the world to live and worship, then return us for a brief moment, perhaps this can reduce our suffering."
text.50:
The keepers of Hell will answer, "Did not messengers come to you with clear explanations, proofs, and arguments demonstrating the Oneness of Allah, guiding you to the path of happiness, and conveying warnings to you about the consequences of forbidden actions you committed, such as denying Allah?" Allah says:

"Did there not come to you messengers from yourselves, reciting to you the verses of your Lord and warning you of the meeting of this Day of yours?" (az-Zumar/39: 71)

The polytheists will answer, "Yes, messengers came to us, inviting us to believe in Allah and His Messenger, but we denied that call and refused to believe. We even opposed and tortured the messengers and those who believed in them."

The keepers of Hell will answer, "If your actions and attitudes towards the messengers during your life in the world were truly as you describe, then plead to Allah yourselves. We will not pray for any disbelievers who deny the messengers. Remember, the prayers of people like you will not be accepted by Allah and will be of no benefit. It is all the same to you whether you pray or not; the punishment will not be reduced in the slightest. Taste the punishment as a consequence of your own deeds."

Regarding the condition of the inhabitants of Hell, at-Tirmidhi narrated from Abu ad-Darda', who said: The inhabitants of Hell will be afflicted with hunger that rivals their punishment. They will ask for food. They will be given food of thorny plants that neither fatten nor satisfy hunger, and they will eat it, but they will become even hungrier. They will ask for help again, and they will be given food that gets stuck in the throat after they eat it. They will say that when they were in the world, if they ate and choked, they would ask for water, so they will ask for help to be given syrup to drink. However, they will be given extremely hot water that is lifted with hooks. When the drink approaches their faces, their faces will be burned. When the drink reaches their stomachs, it will destroy their intestines and what is in their stomachs. Finally, they will ask the angels for help, saying, "Plead to your Lord that He lighten the punishment for us for one day." The angels will answer, "Did not your messengers come to you with clear proofs?" They will answer, "Yes, they did." (The keepers of Hell) will say, "Then plead (yourselves!)" But the supplication of the disbelievers is nothing but error. (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abu ad-Darda')
text.51:
In this verse, Allah promises the believers assistance and victory in facing their enemies. Allah states that He will certainly make His messengers victorious over their enemies and will help and make the believers happy in this life and the hereafter.

The ways and forms of Allah's help are varied. Sometimes it is by elevating their position and power over their enemies, as was given to David and Solomon. Sometimes it is by granting them victory over their enemies, as was given to the Prophet Muhammad (saw). Sometimes it is also by inflicting misery and disaster upon them, as was experienced by Pharaoh and his people. And sometimes it is by destroying the disbelievers and saving the messengers and the believers with them, as was experienced by the Prophets Saleh, Hud, Shu'aib, and Noah and their people.

Likewise, Allah gives help to the messengers and the believers on the Day of Judgment, which is the day the witnesses stand, consisting of the angels, the prophets, and the believers. On that day, they will be witnesses to all the deeds of the disbelievers and to the knowledge of the messengers to them, but they denied it.
text.52:
This verse explains that on the day when the witnesses present their testimony, the reasons they put forward will no longer be of any benefit, nor will any apologies they offer be accepted, because everything they said and did was nothing but slander and lies.

Allah says:

Then their only excuse was to say, "By Allah, our Lord, we were not those who associated others with Allah." (al-An'am/6: 23)

On that day, the disbelievers will be distanced from the mercy of Allah, and they will receive a very painful punishment in Hell.
text.53:
In these verses, Allah explains the various kinds of assistance He has given to the messengers in the world, including giving Moses various miracles, various laws that regulate human life so that they may live happily in this world and the hereafter, and revealing to him the Torah to be a guide for mankind. Then the Torah was inherited by the descendants and those after them and became a reminder for those who are wise and keeps them away from doubts and bad assumptions.

Allah's word:

Indeed, We sent down the Torah, in which was guidance and light. The prophets who submitted [to Allah] judged by it for the Jews, as did the rabbis and scholars by that with which they were entrusted of the Scripture of Allah, and they were witnesses thereto. (al-Ma'idah/5: 44)
text.54:
In these verses, Allah explains the various kinds of assistance He has given to the messengers in the world, including giving Moses various miracles, various laws that regulate human life so that they may live happily in this world and the hereafter, and revealing to him the Torah to be a guide for mankind. Then the Torah was inherited by his descendants and those after them and became a reminder for those who have understanding and kept them away from doubts and bad prejudices.

Allah's word:

"Indeed, We sent down the Torah, in which was guidance and light. The prophets who submitted [to Allah] judged by it for the Jews, as did the rabbis and scholars by that with which they were entrusted of the Scripture of Allah, and they were witnesses thereto." (al-Ma'idah/5: 44)
text.55:
Allah's help to the apostles and those who believe is one of the sunnatullah (divine laws) as was once bestowed upon Moses. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad was asked to be patient with the attitudes and actions of the polytheists who mocked the verses of Allah. Allah will surely help him by strengthening the ranks of the Muslims and elevating the position of the Islamic religion above the beliefs they adhered to. The Prophet Muhammad was commanded to always repent and glorify Allah morning and evening, as Allah says:

And establish prayer at the two ends of the day and in the first part of the night. Indeed, good deeds do away with misdeeds. That is a reminder for those who remember (Allah). (Hud/11: 114)

By always praying, remembering Allah, and glorifying Him morning and evening, the Messenger of Allah worshipped as the angels do. Allah says:

And to Him belongs whoever is in the heavens and earth. And those near Him are not prevented by arrogance from His worship, nor do they tire. They exalt [Him] night and day [without ceasing]. (al-Anbiya'/21: 19-20)

The Messenger of Allah (saw) was commanded to repent not because he had committed a sin, but the intention was that by frequently repenting and asking for forgiveness, the soul becomes more pure and clean, without any dirt contaminating it. If the Prophet, who is free from all sins, is still told to repent, then for his ummah and followers it is even more so. They must quickly and more frequently repent.

From this verse, it can be understood that the Qur'an teaches that believers should always repent, ask forgiveness from Allah, and do good deeds. If a person has repented and asked for forgiveness, then his soul becomes pure and clean. Deeds done by a person with a clean soul will be directly accepted by Allah.

From this verse, it can be understood that a person whose heart is not pure and clean because he does not repent and ask forgiveness from Allah, then his deeds are not accepted by Allah or are not considered as righteous deeds.
text.56:
Allah's help to the messengers and those who believe is one of the sunnatullah (divine laws) as was once bestowed upon Moses. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad was asked to be patient with the attitudes and actions of the polytheists who mocked the verses of Allah. Allah will surely help him by strengthening the ranks of the Muslims and elevating the position of Islam above the beliefs they adhere to. The Prophet Muhammad was commanded to always repent and glorify Allah morning and evening, as Allah says:

And establish prayer at the two ends of the day and in the first part of the night. Indeed, good deeds do away with misdeeds. That is a reminder for those who remember (Allah). (Hud/11: 114)

By always praying, remembering Allah, and glorifying Him morning and evening, the Messenger of Allah worships as the angels do. Allah says:

And to Him belongs whoever is in the heavens and earth. And those near Him are not prevented by arrogance from His worship, nor do they tire. They exalt [Him] night and day, without cease. (al-Anbiya'/21: 19-20)

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was commanded to repent not because he had committed sins, but the intention was that by frequently repenting and asking for forgiveness, the soul becomes purer and cleaner, without any impurity contaminating it. If the Prophet, who is free from all sins, is still told to repent, then for his ummah (community) and followers, it is even more so. They must repent quickly and more often.

From this verse, it can be understood that the Qur'an teaches that believers should always repent, ask forgiveness from Allah, and do good deeds. If a person has repented and asked for forgiveness, then his soul becomes pure and clean. The deeds done by a person with a pure soul will be directly accepted by Allah.

From this verse, it can be understood that a person whose heart is not pure and clean because he does not repent and ask forgiveness from Allah, then his deeds are not accepted by Allah or are not considered as righteous deeds.
text.57:
In this verse, it is stated that those who deny the call of the Messenger and refute the verses of Allah are those whose hearts are filled with arrogance and pride. They are reluctant to accept the truth due to the influence of their desires. They want to be in power and be made leaders in society, and feel they are the most powerful. This desire is what causes them to deny the verses of Allah. According to them, this desire will not be achieved if they follow the call of the Messenger, because following the call of the Messenger means abandoning the religion of their ancestors that they have respected all this time.

Then Allah explains that even though the disbelievers always try to destroy the Prophet Muhammad and his followers, they will not achieve that goal. Because Allah always helps the Prophet Muhammad by humiliating, disgracing, and destroying his enemies and their efforts.

Allah then commands the Prophet to always seek protection from Him to thwart the schemes and efforts of the polytheists. Allah is All-Hearing of every request and supplication of His servants, knowing every vibration of the soul and seeing all the deeds of His servants.

(57) In this verse, Allah presents one of the proofs of the Day of Resurrection on the Day of Judgment. He explains that creating the heavens and the earth is more "difficult" and "arduous" than creating humans, both when creating them for the first time and when repeating it again. The heavens and the earth and all their contents are infinitely vast and large. The number of planets there is countless. The number of animals and plants that exist on it is countless. The mountains and flowing rivers cannot all be traced by humans. The laws and knowledge related to it cannot be fully known by humans. Therefore, the polytheists should never think that Allah, who created the heavens and the earth and the humans in them, is unable to resurrect humans again on the Day of Judgment or revive those who have died. Nothing is difficult for Allah, everything is easy for Him.

Allah says:

"Do they not see that Allah, Who created the heavens and the earth and did not tire in their creation, is able to give life to the dead? Yes, indeed; He is All-Powerful over everything." (al-A.hqaf/46: 33)

Verse 57 of Surah az-Zumar seems to emphasize that the creation of the universe is far more complex (larger) than the creation of humans (this is certainly from the human perspective because for Allah nothing is difficult at all). Whereas from the number of writings resulting from thoughts and findings, the disclosure of the theory of the creation of the universe is more numerous and more rapidly developing compared to the development of the theory of the origin of humans, which until now is still filled with unanswered questions and controversial facts. Judging from the time of its existence scientifically, humans (homo sapiens) are estimated to have appeared 40,000 years ago, this period of time is nothing compared to the age of the universe which is estimated to have existed since 7 billion years ago, especially when compared to the history of human civilization whose traces were found only about 7000 years ago. It seems that our knowledge about the creation of the universe is actually not much more than what we know about the origin of humans.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that the proofs presented are there, and very few people are willing to think to seek the ultimate truth. They are too influenced by desires and worldly pleasures which are only temporary in nature. They also do not want to listen and realize that Allah is All-Powerful, nothing can defeat Him.
text.58:
This verse explains that those who are disbelievers, blind to the truth, unwilling to see and contemplate the signs of Allah's power and greatness in the heavens and the earth, are not the same in the sight of Allah as those who believe, who seek the truth, striving to convince themselves by studying and reflecting on the signs of Allah's power and greatness, so that they know that the creation of the earth and the heavens and what is in them is greater and more difficult than creating mankind. Therefore, resurrecting mankind is easy for Allah. Likewise, those who believe and do righteous deeds are not the same as those who disbelieve and always commit deeds forbidden by Allah.

Indeed, only a few people are willing to contemplate and think about the arguments presented to them, and few are willing to take lessons. If they were willing to reflect so that they knew the truth, they would surely also know the mistakes they had made and would not repeat them.
text.59:
After Allah explained the proofs of the Day of Judgment and the Day of Resurrection, He affirmed that the Day of Judgment is certain to come. At that time, all of humanity will be resurrected, and each of them will have their deeds reckoned with full justice before the court of Allah. No one can escape from the judgment of God.

Even though the Day of Judgment is certain to come, and it has been affirmed that the disbelievers will enter Hell and the believers will enter Paradise, very few people are willing to believe and have faith; in fact, they deny it.
text.60:
In this verse, Allah commands people to pray to Him. If they pray, He will surely grant that prayer.

Ibn 'Abbas, adh-Dahhak, and Mujahid interpret this verse as, "Your Lord says, 'Worship Me, and I will reward you.'" According to them, in the Qur'an, the word *doa* (prayer) can also be interpreted as worship, as in Allah's saying:

What they invoke besides Him are only female [deities], and they invoke nothing but a rebellious devil. (an-Nisa'/4: 117)

In a hadith, the Prophet said:

Prayer is worship. (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi from an-Nu'man bin Basyir)

Some scholars of tafsir are of the opinion that *doa* in this verse means "supplication."

Actually, *doa* and worship are the same from a linguistic perspective. Only the former means specific, while the latter means general. Prayer is one form or way of worship. This is based on the hadith:

Prayer is the essence of worship. (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi from Anas bin Malik)

And the hadith of the Prophet saw:

It is narrated from 'Aisha, she said, "The Prophet saw was asked, 'Which worship is the most excellent?' He replied, 'A person's prayer for himself.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

Based on the hadith above, *doa* in this verse can be interpreted as worship. This is strengthened by the continuation of the verse which means: "Indeed, those who disdain My worship will enter Hell in humiliation."

This verse is a warning and a severe threat to those who are reluctant to worship Allah. This verse is also a statement from Allah to His believing servants so that they may obtain goodness and happiness in this world and the hereafter. It is as if Allah is saying, "O My servants, humble yourselves to Me, always worship and pray to Me. I will accept the worship and prayer that you perform sincerely, grant your requests, and forgive your sins."
text.61:
In this verse, Allah commands mankind to worship Him for the following reasons:

1. The One who commands worship is the Lord who made the night as a time of rest, and prepares new energy so that one can strive again the next day. At night, people generally sleep because it is a bodily need that must be fulfilled.

2. The One who made the day bright, illuminating the universe so that people can strive to fulfill their needs in life.

3. Because Allah has countless bounties prepared for all of His creatures, and these bounties will never run out.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that most people do not want to be grateful for the blessings of Allah that have been bestowed upon them. They deny the blessings, as if they obtained those blessings solely through their own efforts.
text.62:
This verse explains that the One who bestows countless blessings upon all creatures is the Lord who deserves to be worshipped, because He is the One who created all creatures.

The disbelievers will be asked why they turn away, refuse to worship, and do not acknowledge the Oneness of Allah. Whereas everything they worship is the creation of Allah, which is not worthy of worship.
text.63: This verse explains that just as the polytheists have gone astray because of worshipping gods other than Allah, so too have those before them gone astray. They denied the verses of Allah and worshipped other gods solely because of their ignorance and following their own desires.
text.64:
This verse explains that Allah made the earth for mankind as a dwelling place. They live on it, enjoying the sustenance bestowed upon them. He also made the sky as a roof and adorned it with glittering stars that appear at night. Because of the orderly movement of the stars, night, day, darkness, and bright light arise.

This verse also explains the proofs of Allah's Oneness and Power that are found within mankind itself. Allah has created mankind in the best form among His creatures and equipped them with body parts that are suitable for the needs and interests of human life itself. He is also the One who gives mankind good food and drink as sustenance from Him. Allah is the Most High Lord, who possesses the universe.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that the Lord who bestows His grace upon mankind is the Lord who must be worshipped. The Most Perfect Lord who possesses the universe. Allah says:

"O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous - (He) who made for you the earth a bed [spread out] and the sky a ceiling and sent down from the sky, rain and brought forth thereby fruits as provision for you. So do not attribute to Allah equals while you know [that there is no equal to Him]." (al-Baqarah/2: 21-22)
text.65:
This verse explains that the God who is worshipped is the Ever-Living God, who never dies. He is the One who gives life and causes death to His creatures; besides Him, none is worthy of worship. Therefore, purify your submission and obedience to Him alone, and never associate partners with Him in any way.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that all praise belongs to Allah, the Lord, the Most Holy. He is the One who possesses all His creatures, whether they are angels, jinn, humans, and all other creatures in this universe. All of them are dependent on Him, so all attributes of greatness and glory belong to Him. Therefore, they always say: "al-hamdulillahi Rabbil 'alamin".
text.66:
In these verses, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to say to the polytheists and disbelievers that Allah forbids him from worshipping the gods they worship, other than Allah.

The meaning of worshipping gods other than Allah is to enslave oneself to something, to consider it to possess unseen power like the power of Allah, to seek help, and to ask something from it. In this verse, it is mentioned that these gods are in the form of idols. However, this understanding includes all kinds of objects or creatures that are worshipped and from whom help is sought, such as rivers, sacred stones, graves considered sacred, and so on.

Furthermore, the Messenger of Allah is commanded to declare that Allah forbids him from worshipping other than Allah, and to present evidence and arguments in the form of verses of the Al-Qur'an, as well as commands to pay attention to the events of this universe. By contemplating the events of nature and the verses of the Al-Qur'an, one will come to the conclusion that only Allah alone deserves to be worshipped.

At the end of this verse, Allah commands us to submit and obey Him, purifying our obedience only to Him, because He is the Lord and Owner of the universe.
text.67:
He is the One who created man from dust, then from a sperm-drop, then from a clot, then from a lump of flesh, then He brings you forth as a child.

The majority of scholars (Jumhur ulama) are of the opinion that what is meant by Allah creating man from dust is the father of mankind, namely Adam, whom Allah created from dust.

Some commentators of the Quran explain that what is meant by Allah creating man from dust is that Allah created man from the essence that comes from the earth. A father and a mother eat food that comes from the earth, from livestock, and plants. Livestock eat plants and develop using substances that come from the earth. The food eaten by the mother or father is the main source for forming the egg cell or sperm. The mother's egg cell meets the father's sperm in the mother's womb, so it becomes a blood clot and so on.

Allah then explains that the man He created from dust experiences life in three stages:

1. Childhood.

2. Adulthood.

3. Old age.

Among people, there are those whom Allah causes to die in childhood, some in adulthood, and some who die after reaching old age. The determination of when a person dies is solely in the hands of Allah.

The process of human creation is explained in this verse so that it can be a material for reflection and thought for people of understanding, so that they believe in Allah, the Creator of all creatures.
text.68: Allah commands the Messenger of Allah to convey to the polytheists that the God who is worthy of worship is the Lord who brings mankind to life from non-existence to existence, revives them after death, and causes all creatures to die at times that He has determined. He is the Almighty and the Creator. If He wills to create something, Allah simply says, "Be," and it is.
text.69:
Allah states to Prophet Muhammad, did he not observe those who dispute the verses of Allah that explain and prove His Oneness and the existence of the Day of Resurrection. Those disbelievers dispute without presenting strong or rationally acceptable evidence. This shows that their disbelief and denial are completely without reason. If there are reasons they put forward, those reasons are solely to avoid the call of Muhammad.

Their attitude is strange and incorrect. If they want to seek the truth and follow the correct belief, there are many proofs they can study and consider to achieve their desires.
text.70:
Those who dispute the verses of Allah are those who deny the verses of the Qur'an revealed by Allah to Muhammad (peace be upon him) and deny everything conveyed by the messengers upon His command.

Within the verses of the Qur'an and what the messengers conveyed are commands to devote oneself solely to Allah, not to worship anything besides Him, to believe in the Day of Resurrection, and laws and guidance for happiness in this life and the hereafter.

Those who disbelieve will soon know the consequences of their disbelief. This is a very stern warning, as Allah says:

"Woe on that Day to the deniers!" (al-Muthaffifin/83: 10)
text.71:
As a consequence of their disbelief, the disbelievers will experience torment in the afterlife, when shackles and chains are placed around their necks, then they are dragged forcefully and burned in hell.

This verse is similar in content and meaning to Allah's saying:

Then surely their return is to the Hell of Jahim. (ash-Shaffat/37: 68)

And Allah's saying:

Seize him and drag him into the midst of the Hellfire, then pour over his head torment of scalding water. "Taste! Indeed, you are the honored, the noble!" Indeed, this is the torment about which you used to doubt. (ad-Dukhan/44: 47-50)
text.72:
As a consequence of their disbelief, the disbelievers will experience torment in the Hereafter, when shackles and chains are placed around their necks, then they are dragged forcefully and burned in Hell.

This verse is similar in content and meaning to Allah's saying:

Then surely their return is to Hellfire. (ash-Shaffat/37: 68)

And Allah's saying:

Seize him and drag him into the midst of the Hellfire, then pour over his head the torment of scalding water. "Taste! Indeed, you are the mighty, the noble!" Indeed, this is the torment about which you used to doubt. (ad-Dukhan/44: 47-50)
text.73:
To the disbelievers who are being afflicted with a very painful torment, questions are posed in a mocking tone to increase the severity of the suffering they are experiencing. These questions are: where are the idols they used to worship besides Allah? The idols that, according to them, were able to release and save them from the torment and disaster of that day.

They answer that those idols have disappeared from them, have gone another way, and left them to be afflicted with disaster and misery on that day. They acknowledge that in reality, during their lives in the world, they followed a false religion and belief and worshipped something unworthy of worship.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that just as Allah has allowed the polytheists to go astray, so that not a single deed is accepted from them as a righteous deed, so too is Allah's attitude towards all the works that the disbelievers have done. They cannot benefit in the slightest from their deeds.
text.74:
To the disbelievers who are being afflicted with a very painful torment, questions are posed in a mocking tone to increase the severity of the suffering they are experiencing. These questions are: where are the idols they used to worship besides Allah? The idols that, according to them, were capable of releasing and saving them from the torment and disaster of that day.

They answer that those idols have disappeared from them, have followed another path, and have left them to be afflicted with disaster and misery on that day. They acknowledge that, in reality, during their lives in the world, they followed a false religion and belief and worshipped something unworthy of worship.

At the end of this verse, it is affirmed that just as Allah has allowed the polytheists to go astray, so that not a single deed is accepted from them as a righteous deed (amal saleh), so too is Allah's attitude towards all the deeds that the disbelievers have done. They cannot derive even the slightest benefit from their deeds.
text.75: This verse explains the reasons why Allah inflicts a painful punishment upon the disbelievers. Among these reasons is that they felt joyful and happy without feeling guilty during their lives in the world, committing acts of shirk, such as worshipping more than one god, worshipping other gods besides worshipping Allah, or acknowledging that there are creatures other than Allah who possess unseen powers equal to His power. In addition to that, they also committed acts of disobedience, and behaved arrogantly, proudly, and unjustly towards people.
text.76: Then the disbelievers were commanded to enter Hell through its gates, according to the state of evil deeds they had committed. They were also commanded to remain in Hell, for that is the appropriate place for those who deny the verses of Allah and are arrogant towards Him.
text.77:
Allah commands His messengers to be patient in the face of the actions of the polytheists who deny and refute His verses. The messengers are also asked to be patient and to trust in Him in the face of their disturbances and threats. Allah declares that His promise to punish the disbelievers is certainly true and will be fulfilled.

Allah says to the Prophet saw that whether He shows him, while the Prophet is still alive, the punishment inflicted upon the polytheists, or does not show the Prophet that punishment by causing him to die before the arrival of the punishment, it will not mean anything to them. On the Day of Resurrection, everything returns to Allah, and then they will be given a fitting recompense.

Another verse with the same meaning as this verse is:

"Then, whether We take you away [in death], We will surely exact retribution from them. Or We show you that [punishment] which We have promised them; indeed, We are fully capable over them." (az-Zukhruf/43: 41-42)
text.78:
This verse explains that Allah has sent messengers and prophets to communities before Prophet Muhammad. Among these prophets and messengers, those whose stories are narrated in the Qur'an number 25, such as Prophet Noah, Idris, Abraham, Moses, Solomon, Jesus, and other messengers. Besides these, many prophets and messengers are not mentioned in the Qur'an.

From Abu Dharr, who said, "I asked, 'O Messenger of Allah, how many prophets are there?' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) replied, '124,000, and among them are 315 messengers. A large number.'" (Narrated by Ahmad)

Every messenger sent by Allah is not capable of creating miracles on their own, but they can be given by Allah. The miracle serves as proof of their prophethood, presented to the people who deny them. The form and nature of the miracle are adjusted to the circumstances, time, and place where the receiving messenger lives, so that the miracle is truly believed by the people at that time. The miracle is given if Allah Himself wills to give it. If Allah does not yet will to give it, then the miracle will not be given, even if the disbelievers ask for it. The miracle is given according to the wisdom and discretion of Allah and also according to the benefit of the people.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that if Allah's punishment has come upon those who deny Him, then Allah settles their affairs with the utmost justice. Allah saves the messengers and those who believe in them from that punishment, and destroys those who disbelieve and associate partners with Him. This can be seen when Allah's punishment befell the people of 'Ad; Allah saved Prophet Hud and those who believed with him. Similarly, the punishment that befell the people of Thamud and so on.
text.79:
Most commentators are of the opinion that what is meant by livestock in this verse is camels, because that animal is the most suitable to the characteristics mentioned in this verse. Ibn Kathir is of the opinion that what is meant is camels, cows, and goats. Camels are useful for eating, milking, used for carrying heavy goods and ridden when traveling. Cows can be used for eating their meat, milking, and using their strength to plow the land. While goats can be eaten for their meat and milked. All these animals can be used for their wool, skin, and hair. Allah says:

"And Allah has made for you from your homes [that is, tents or houses] of the skins of animals, which you find light on your day of travel and on your day of residence; and from their wool, fur and hair is furnishing and enjoyment for a time." (an-Nahl/16: 80)

And His saying:

"And the grazing livestock He has created for you; in them is warmth and [numerous] benefits, and from them you eat. And for you in them is [the enjoyment of] beauty when you bring them home and when you drive them out to pasture. And they carry your loads to a land you could not have reached except with difficulty. Indeed, your Lord is Kind and Merciful." (an-Nahl/16: 5-7)

Camels are the animals most widely used by people living in the desert, as if camels cannot be separated from their lives and livelihoods. It is the camel that takes them to various countries in trade. Camels are their loyal companions when they are in the middle of the vast desert.

Therefore, if camels are presented by these verses to the Arabs, as one of the animals that is of great benefit, then the meaning of the parable can be understood by their minds. In the Middle Ages, the Arabs were the nation that connected the West and the East. At that time, there was trade from East to West, bringing spices to the West, and bringing handicrafts to the East.

In the East, the spices were brought to South Arabia or the Persian Gulf, then the goods were taken to Turkey through the vast desert. The main means of transportation used by the Arabs at that time was the camel.

In addition to providing examples of the benefits of livestock, namely milk, energy, and so on, this verse underlines its widespread application for transportation, especially in the term "bahtera," which generically means a ship, meaning a sea travel vehicle. However, considering that the Qur'an is the last holy book revealed to mankind until the end of time, the word "bahtera" needs to be expanded to mean all transportation vehicles, whether at sea, lakes, rivers, swamps, or land. This also includes transportation vehicles in the air (atmosphere) or in outer space where there is no air.

Therefore, transportation vehicles include trains, bullet trains (shinkansen in Japan), sky lifts (lines) (vehicles that hang and move in the air above a cable), up to hovercraft, which are vehicles in swamps or marshes. This includes speedboats that hover above the water surface and can glide by occasionally touching the water surface and moving a few centimeters above it. In this category there is also the levitation train which is lifted a few centimeters above the rails and does not touch them. Therefore, the vehicle moves without friction that hinders movement from the rails. The train can levitate without touching the rails because it is loaded with the same magnet as the rails so that there is repulsion between the train and the rails, so that the train levitates, moving without touching the surface of the rails, thus free from friction. This list of vehicles can be revised with space vehicles such as airplanes to outer space vehicles in the form of rockets and satellites.

Of course, this list of vehicles on land, sea, and air needs to be revised with the discovery of new vehicles in accordance with technological advances, but basically all forms and transportation vehicles used by humans move, move, and are dynamic to more quickly achieve our life goals that are pleasing to Allah.

text.81: Thus does Allah show mankind the signs of His power and greatness. In truth, there is not a single one of these signs that cannot be seen or that is inconsistent with reason, so there is no way for mankind to deny them. If they deny them, then the reason for their denial is merely a fabricated excuse.
text.82:
Through this verse, Allah questions whether the polytheists of Mecca, who deny the verses of Allah conveyed to them, have never walked and traveled to other lands? In fact, they are travelers and wayfarers who have gone to various countries for trade. They went to Yemen, South Arabia, and Syria in every season and time, according to the form of trade at that time. In their travels, they passed through lands that were once inhabited by ancient peoples, such as the land of the 'Ad people, Thamud, the inhabitants of Aikah, Egypt, Babylon, and so on.

From the remnants of ruins they saw in those lands, and the stories they received from their ancestors, they knew that in those lands there were once mighty peoples, with high cultures, who had conquered surrounding lands. They carved mountains for their homes, built sturdy pyramids, and so on. However, because of their denial of the messengers of Allah who were sent, they were afflicted with the punishment of Allah. At that time, nothing could save them from the punishment of Allah. The polytheists of Mecca, who have not yet been able to match the achievements of those ancient peoples, will experience the same fate as them if they continue to deny the prophethood of Muhammad (saw). No one can save them from the punishment of Allah.
text.83:
In this verse, it is mentioned that messengers sent by Allah had come to previous communities, bringing strong and clear proofs and explanations. However, they still denied and even opposed the call of these messengers. They showed the messengers how strong their belief was in the religion they adhered to. They thought that the knowledge they had acquired was unparalleled, so they mocked the messengers. These disbelievers will be afflicted with severe torment in the Hereafter.

Their sayings are mentioned in Allah's words:

"And there is nothing that destroys us except time." (al-Jathiyah/45: 24)

And Allah's words:

"If Allah had willed, we would not have associated [anything] with Him, nor would our fathers..." (al-An'am/6: 148)
text.84:
This verse explains the true nature and belief of humans in Allah. Humans fundamentally believe that God is One, He is the Almighty and the One who bestows blessings upon His servants. This belief can be obscured by circumstances that influence human life. When they are in power, wealthy, and controlled by their desires, they forget Allah, even seeking other gods to worship, according to the demands of their desires. If they are afflicted by danger, calamity, sadness, and so on, they remember and submit themselves to the God who created them. At that moment, they deny the gods they have fabricated.

Allah has presented many examples and parables in His verses regarding this matter. There are also many people who possess such characteristics, such as Pharaoh, Qarun, and so on.
text.85:
This verse affirms that the declaration of faith of people as described in the previous verse is of no benefit once Allah's punishment has arrived. The door to repentance has been closed to them, as Allah said to Pharaoh when he was about to drown:

"Until when Pharaoh was about to drown, he said, "I believe that there is no deity except the One in whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am of those who submit (to Him)." Now? And you had disobeyed [Him] before and were of the corrupters." (Yunus/10: 90-91)

This verse serves as a warning that faith will be beneficial to a person if they believe in Allah during their life in this fleeting world, their mind and heart feel the greatness and power of Allah, and they feel that their life and death depend on Him. If they commit a mistake, they immediately repent and promise not to repeat the mistake.

What has been explained are the laws of God that apply to everyone. Faith is of no benefit when they see the punishment. At that time, faith is of no use, and all those who disbelieve will be at a loss.
